ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about different measures of inequality and how they are all related. I also learned about how these vary between countries and how technology and religion are involved

I learned a great deal about the income inequality in the US and in the world.  Particularly, we learned a great deal about the origins of the current high (and increasing) levels of inequality throughout the world, as well as ways to ameliorate them.  In particular, we learned about taxes, sociopolitical institutions, and some microeconomic theories behind the increase in inequality.

This course covered several topics related to income inequality and potential policy solutions. We focused specifically on comparing and contrasting the existing literature to draw conclusions regarding income inequality.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was very strong! I love the professor and how it was structured. One weakness was that the questions were vague sometimes

Strengths:  Lots of great content, the readings are interesting, the professor is great, there is a healthy mix of macro and microeconomics 

Weaknesses:  The math can be difficult for those who have not taken calculus (though that's only in the first half of the course, mostly)

There were many strengths to this course. The content was very tailored and each week had a specific focus that allowed us to really gain a deep understanding of income inequality. The professor was also really committed to helping us understand the material and encouraged regular participation. The fact that it was such a small lecture really allowed us to talk about the material and develop a stronger relationship with the professor. A small way it could be improved is by having pre-selected dates for the midterm/final/paper so that we can plan our schedules more in advance.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really enjoyed how we went over the readings together but I felt that the cold calling was at times vague

I enjoyed the discussion.  The professor made heavy use of the socratic method, particularly asking a lot of questions from the students throughout class.  While I am not much of a fan of cold-calling, it did help make the class move along well.  We had a fairly small class size, which didn't help much on this end, but it made us more comfortable speaking, so even if we answered incorrectly, it didn't matter much.  Overall, the professor encouraging discussion and prodding students along helped move discussions better.

The lecture was done in the best way possible for the virtual environment, but obviously an in-person class where we can see the board better and engage in a more natural way would be better for the future.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes I would!! The professor is amazing and he really cares about the students. You also learn so much and he makes the material very accessible.

I would certainly recommend this course to other students, particular those who are interested in learning about inequality but don't have much of an economics background apart from a few introductory courses.  I would not recommend the course to students who don't have an understanding of calculus, however, because it is important from understanding the microeconomic sections of the course at the beginning.  Overall, I would recommend to any economics  major and a political science major with a basic understanding of economics and a workable understanding of calculus.

Yes! As someone who is super interested in this topic, I found the material to be really fulfilling. Moreover, the professor is really committed to helping you learn and it is not a super stress-inducing class. I looked forward to class each week.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
